author: Ruohang Feng (rh@vonng.com)
description: Overview for VictoriaMetrics vmalert v1.117.0 or higher

panels.description: All VMAlert instances
How long the VMAlert instance has been running
Total number of loaded alerting rules across selected instances and groups
Number of alerts currently in firing state
Number of alerts currently in pending state
Total number of loaded recording rules across selected instances and groups
Total errors from alerting and recording rules
Recording rules that produce no data (may be misconfigured)
Current resident memory usage of the process
Shows the number of fired alerts by job.
panels.title: Alerts fired total ($ins)

panels.description: Top $topk groups by evaluation duration. Shows groups that take the most of time during the evaluation across all instances.

targets.expr:
topk($topk, max(sum(
    rate(vmalert_iteration_duration_seconds_sum{ins=~"$ins", group=~"$group", file=~"$file"}[$__rate_interval])
/
    rate(vmalert_iteration_duration_seconds_count{ins=~"$ins", group=~"$group", file=~"$file"}[$__rate_interval])
) by(job, instance, group, file)) 
by(job, group, file))

panels.title: Top $topk groups avg evaluation duration ($group)

panels.description: Shows how many requests (executions) per second vmalert sends to the configured datasource.
panels.title: Rules execution rate ($ins)

panels.description: Shows the error rate while executing configured rules. Non-zero value means there are some issues with existing rules. Check the logs to get more details.
panels.title: Rules execution errors ($ins)

targets.expr: job:syslog ip:$ip unit:vmalert | stats count() as count

panels.description: syslog of grafana-server in $ins @ $ip

How much resident memory (RAM) the process is actually using, compared to its allowed container or system limit.

- Good: Below 70% most of the time, maybe spiking a bit under load.
- Bad: Above 90% for more than 5 minutes = risk of out-of-memory (OOM) kill.
panels.title: Memory usage % ($ins)

panels.description:
Shows the CPU usage percentage per vmalert instance. 
If you think that usage is abnormal or unexpected pls file an issue and attach CPU profile if possible.
panels.title: CPU usage %($ins)

panels.description:
Share for memory allocated by the process itself. When memory usage reaches 100% it will be likely OOM-killed.
Safe memory usage % considered to be below 80%
panels.title: RSS anonymous memory % usage

panels.description: Shows the max number of CPU cores used  by a `job` and the corresponding limit.
panels.title: CPU usage ($ins)

panels.description:
Amount of used RSS memory

If you think that usage is abnormal or unexpected, please file an issue and attach memory profile if possible.
panels.title: Memory usage ($ins)

panels.description:
CPU pressure based on [Pressure Stall Information](https://docs.kernel.org/accounting/psi.html). Helps troubleshoot high CPU usage or throttling.
Lower is better.

- waiting: The percentage of time at least one task in the process was ready to run (runnable) but couldn't get scheduled on the CPU.
- stalled: The percentage of time all tasks in the process (except idle ones) were unable to get CPU time — a full CPU stall.

If there's a CPU burst, it's normal to see waiting or stalled > 1%. It only becomes a concern if it consistently climbs above 5–10% and aligns with latency spikes or GC slowdowns.
panels.title: CPU pressure

panels.description:
Shows memory pressure based on [Pressure Stall Information](https://docs.kernel.org/accounting/psi.html).
Lower is better.

- waiting: Time fraction where at least one thread was blocked on memory.
- stalled: Time fraction where every thread was blocked on memory (severe pressure).

If queries slow down and both series spike, the host is likely limited by RAM or I/O throughput.
panels.title: Memory pressure

panels.description:
Panel shows the percentage of open file descriptors in the OS.
Reaching the limit of open files can cause various issues and must be prevented.

See how to change limits here https://medium.com/@muhammadtriwibowo/set-permanently-ulimit-n-open-files-in-ubuntu-4d61064429a
panels.title: Open FDs usage % ($ins)

panels.description:
Shows the time goroutines have spent in runnable state before actually running. The lower is better.

High values or values exceeding the threshold is usually a sign of            insufficient CPU resources or CPU throttling. 

Verify that service has enough CPU resources. Otherwise, the service could work unreliably with delays in processing.
panels.title: Go scheduling latency

panels.description:
Shows the percent of CPU spent on garbage collection.

If % is high, then CPU usage can be decreased by changing GOGC to higher values. Increasing GOGC value will increase memory usage, and decrease CPU usage.

Try searching for keyword `GOGC` at https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/troubleshooting/
panels.title: CPU spent on GC ($ins)

panels.description: Shows the rate of allocations in memory. Sudden increase in allocations would mean increased pressure on Go Garbage Collector and can saturate CPU resources of the application.
panels.title: Memory allocations rate

targets.expr: sum(flag{is_set="true", ins=~"$ins"}) by(job, instance, name, value)

panels.description:
Missed evaluation means that group evaluation time takes longer than the configured evaluation interval. 
This may result in missed alerting notifications or recording rules samples. Try increasing evaluation interval or concurrency for such groups. See https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/vmalert/#groups

If rule expressions are taking longer than expected, please see https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/troubleshooting/#slow-queries."
panels.title: Missed evaluations ($ins)

panels.description: Shows the number of restarts per job. The chart can be useful to identify periodic process restarts and correlate them with potential issues or anomalies. Normally, processes shouldn't restart unless restart was inited by user. The reason of restarts should be figured out by checking the logs of each specific service.
panels.title: Restarts ($job)

panels.description: Shows top $topk current active (firing) alerting rules.

targets.expr: topk($topk, sum(vmalert_alerts_firing{ins=~"$ins", group=~"$group", file=~"$file"}) by(job, group, file, alertname) > 0)

panels.title: Top $topk active alerts ($group)

panels.description: Shows the events when rule execution resulted into an error. Check the logs for more details.

targets.expr: sum(increase(vmalert_alerting_rules_errors_total{ins=~"$ins", group=~"$group", file=~"$file"}[$__rate_interval])) by(job, group, file, alertname) > 0

panels.title: Errors ($group)

panels.description:
Shows the current pending alerting rules per group.
By pending means the rule which remains active less than configured `for` parameter.

targets.expr: sum(vmalert_alerts_pending{ins=~"$ins", group=~"$group", file=~"$file"}) by(job, group, file, alertname) > 0

panels.title: Pending ($group)

panels.description: Shows the error rate for the attempts to send alerts to Alertmanager. If not zero it means there issues on attempt to send notification to Alertmanager and some alerts may be not delivered properly. Check the logs for more details.
panels.title: Errors rate to Alertmanager

panels.description: Shows how many alerts are sent to Alertmanager per second. Only active alerts are sent.
panels.title: Requests rate to Alertmanager by job ($group)

panels.description: Shows the top $topk recording rules which generate the most of [samples](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/keyconcepts/#raw-samples). Each generated sample is basically a time series which then ingested into configured remote storage. Rules with high numbers may cause the most pressure on the remote database and become a source of too high cardinality.
panels.title: Top $topk rules by produced samples ($group)

panels.description:
Shows the rules which do not produce any [samples](https://docs.victoriametrics.com/victoriametrics/keyconcepts/#raw-samples) during the evaluation. Usually it means that such rules are misconfigured, since they give no output during the evaluation.
Please check if rule's expression is correct and it is working as expected.

targets.expr: count(vmalert_recording_rules_last_evaluation_samples{ins=~"$ins", group=~"$group", file=~"$file"} < 1) by(job, group, file, recording)

panels.title: Rules with 0 produced samples ($group)

targets.expr: sum(increase(vmalert_recording_rules_errors_total{ins=~"$ins", group=~"$group", file=~"$file"}[$__rate_interval])) by(job, group, file, recording) > 0

panels.description: Shows the number of datapoints dropped by vmalert while sending to the configured remote write URL. vmalert performs up to 5 retries before dropping the data. Check vmalert's error logs for the specific error message.
panels.title: Datapoints drop rate ($ins)

panels.description: Shows current number of established connections to remote write endpoints.
panels.title: Connections ($ins)

panels.description: Shows the global rate for number of written bytes via remote write connections.
panels.title: Bytes write rate ($ins)

title: Victoria Alert
